deck_info.name: Comprehensive Complex Subjects Master Deck
deck_info.description: Complete complex subjects deck covering Physics, Chemistry, Mathematics, Biology, and Computer Science

physics.name: Physics

cards.back: A push or pull that can change an object's motion. Measured in Newtons (N). Example: Gravity pulling objects toward Earth.
The amount of matter in an object. Measured in kilograms (kg). Mass is constant regardless of location.
The force of gravity acting on an object's mass. Weight = mass × gravitational acceleration (W = mg).
The rate of change of velocity with time. Measured in meters per second squared (m/s²).
The product of an object's mass and velocity (p = mv). Momentum is conserved in closed systems.
The ability to do work. Types include kinetic (motion), potential (position), and thermal (heat) energy.
The rate at which work is done or energy is transferred. Measured in Watts (W). Power = Work/Time.
Force applied over a distance. Work = Force × Distance × cos(θ). Measured in Joules (J).
The ratio of useful work output to total energy input. Efficiency = (Useful Output/Total Input) × 100%.

cards.front: Define and explain: Conservation of Energy
cards.back: Energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed from one form to another.
A measure of the average kinetic energy of particles in a substance. Measured in Kelvin (K) or Celsius (°C).
Energy transferred between objects due to temperature difference. Heat flows from hot to cold objects.
The total energy of all particles in a system, including kinetic and potential energy.
A measure of disorder or randomness in a system. Entropy always increases in isolated systems.

cards.front: Define and explain: First Law of Thermodynamics
cards.back: Energy cannot be created or destroyed. The change in internal energy equals heat added minus work done.

cards.front: Define and explain: Second Law of Thermodynamics
cards.back: Heat cannot spontaneously flow from a colder body to a hotter body. Entropy increases over time.
A disturbance that transfers energy through a medium or space without transferring matter.
The maximum displacement of a wave from its equilibrium position. Determines wave intensity.
The distance between two consecutive points in phase on a wave (e.g., crest to crest).
The number of complete wave cycles per second. Measured in Hertz (Hz).
The speed at which a wave travels through a medium. Wave Speed = Frequency × Wavelength.
The interaction of two or more waves. Constructive interference increases amplitude; destructive decreases it.
A fundamental property of matter. Like charges repel; opposite charges attract. Measured in Coulombs (C).
A region around a charged object where other charges experience electric force. Field lines show direction.
The rate of flow of electric charge. Current = Charge/Time. Measured in Amperes (A).
The difference in electric potential between two points. Voltage = Work/Charge. Measured in Volts (V).
The opposition to electric current flow. Resistance = Voltage/Current. Measured in Ohms (Ω).
The relationship between voltage, current, and resistance: V = IR (Voltage = Current × Resistance).
The emission of electrons from a metal surface when light shines on it. Supports particle nature of light.
The concept that light and matter exhibit both wave-like and particle-like properties.
The branch of physics that describes the behavior of matter and energy at atomic and subatomic scales.
Einstein's theory that space and time are interconnected, and that the speed of light is constant for all observers.
The splitting of a heavy nucleus into smaller nuclei, releasing energy. Used in nuclear power plants.
The combining of light nuclei to form heavier nuclei, releasing energy. Powers the Sun and stars.

physics.description: Physical laws, mechanics, thermodynamics, waves, electricity, and modern physics

chemistry.name: Chemistry

cards.back: The smallest unit of an element that retains the properties of that element. Consists of protons, neutrons, and electrons.
Positively charged subatomic particle found in the nucleus. Determines the element's identity.
Neutrally charged subatomic particle found in the nucleus. Contributes to atomic mass.
Negatively charged subatomic particle that orbits the nucleus. Participates in chemical bonding.

cards.front: Explain the chemical concept: Atomic Number
cards.back: The number of protons in an atom's nucleus. Determines the element's identity.

cards.front: Explain the chemical concept: Atomic Mass
cards.back: The total mass of an atom, including protons, neutrons, and electrons.
Atoms of the same element with different numbers of neutrons, resulting in different atomic masses.

cards.front: Explain the chemical concept: Ionic Bond
cards.back: Chemical bond formed by the transfer of electrons from one atom to another, creating oppositely charged ions.

cards.front: Explain the chemical concept: Covalent Bond
cards.back: Chemical bond formed by the sharing of electrons between atoms.

cards.front: Explain the chemical concept: Metallic Bond
cards.back: Chemical bond formed by the attraction between metal cations and delocalized electrons.

cards.front: Explain the chemical concept: Polar Bond
cards.back: Covalent bond where electrons are shared unequally, creating partial positive and negative charges.

cards.front: Explain the chemical concept: Nonpolar Bond
cards.back: Covalent bond where electrons are shared equally between atoms.

cards.front: Explain the chemical concept: Hydrogen Bond
cards.back: Weak attraction between a hydrogen atom and an electronegative atom (usually oxygen, nitrogen, or fluorine).

cards.front: Explain the chemical concept: Chemical Reaction
cards.back: Process where substances are transformed into new substances with different properties.
Substance that participates in a chemical reaction and is consumed.
Substance that is formed as a result of a chemical reaction.
Substance that increases the rate of a chemical reaction without being consumed.
Biological catalyst that speeds up biochemical reactions in living organisms.

cards.front: Explain the chemical concept: Activation Energy
cards.back: Minimum energy required for a chemical reaction to occur.
State of matter with definite shape and volume. Particles are closely packed and vibrate in fixed positions.
State of matter with definite volume but no definite shape. Particles are close but can move past each other.
State of matter with no definite shape or volume. Particles are far apart and move freely.
State of matter where atoms are ionized and electrons are free. Found in stars and lightning.

cards.front: Explain the chemical concept: Phase Change
cards.back: Transition between different states of matter (solid, liquid, gas) due to temperature or pressure changes.

cards.front: Explain the chemical concept: Melting Point
cards.back: Temperature at which a solid changes to a liquid.

cards.front: Explain the chemical concept: Boiling Point
cards.back: Temperature at which a liquid changes to a gas.

chemistry.description: Atomic structure, chemical bonding, reactions, and states of matter

cards.back: A symbol (usually a letter) that represents an unknown value or a value that can change.
A mathematical statement that two expressions are equal, containing an equals sign (=).
A mathematical statement that two expressions are not equal, using symbols like <, >, ≤, ≥, ≠.
A relationship between two sets where each input has exactly one output. Often written as f(x).
An expression with multiple terms, each containing variables raised to whole number powers.

cards.front: Define the mathematical concept: Quadratic Equation
cards.back: A polynomial equation of degree 2, in the form ax² + bx + c = 0.
The process of breaking down a polynomial into a product of simpler polynomials.
A location in space with no size or dimension. Represented by a dot.
A straight path that extends infinitely in both directions. Has length but no width.
A flat surface that extends infinitely in all directions. Has length and width but no height.
The figure formed by two rays sharing a common endpoint. Measured in degrees or radians.
A polygon with three sides and three angles. Sum of angles equals 180°.
A set of points equidistant from a center point. Defined by radius and circumference.

cards.front: Define the mathematical concept: Pythagorean Theorem
cards.back: In a right triangle, a² + b² = c², where c is the hypotenuse.
The rate of change of a function with respect to its variable. Represents slope of tangent line.
The area under a curve or the accumulation of a quantity over an interval.
The value that a function approaches as the input approaches a certain value.
A function is continuous if there are no breaks, jumps, or holes in its graph.
The process of finding the derivative of a function.
The process of finding the integral of a function.
The average of a set of numbers, calculated by summing all values and dividing by the count.
The middle value in a set of numbers when arranged in order.
The value that appears most frequently in a set of numbers.

cards.front: Define the mathematical concept: Standard Deviation
cards.back: A measure of how spread out numbers are from the mean.
The likelihood of an event occurring, expressed as a number between 0 and 1.
A measure of the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables.

biology.name: Biology

cards.back: The basic unit of life. All living organisms are composed of one or more cells.
The control center of the cell, containing DNA and regulating cell activities.
Organelles that produce energy through cellular respiration. Known as the 'powerhouse of the cell.'
Organelles in plant cells that carry out photosynthesis, converting sunlight into chemical energy.

cards.front: Explain the biological concept: Cell Membrane
cards.back: The outer boundary of the cell that controls what enters and exits.
The gel-like substance inside the cell where organelles are suspended.
Deoxyribonucleic acid, the molecule that carries genetic information in all living organisms.
A segment of DNA that codes for a specific protein or trait.
A structure made of DNA and proteins that carries genetic information.
A change in the DNA sequence that can result in different traits or genetic disorders.
The passing of traits from parents to offspring through genes.

cards.front: Explain the biological concept: Natural Selection
cards.back: The process where organisms with favorable traits are more likely to survive and reproduce.
The process of change in living organisms over time, resulting in new species.
A trait that helps an organism survive and reproduce in its environment.
The formation of new species from existing ones through evolutionary processes.
The preserved remains or traces of ancient organisms, providing evidence of evolution.

cards.front: Explain the biological concept: Common Ancestor
cards.back: An organism from which two or more species evolved.
The complete disappearance of a species from Earth.
A community of living organisms interacting with their physical environment.

cards.front: Explain the biological concept: Food Chain
cards.back: A linear sequence showing how energy and nutrients flow from one organism to another.

cards.front: Explain the biological concept: Food Web
cards.back: A complex network of interconnected food chains in an ecosystem.
The variety of life in an ecosystem, including different species and genetic diversity.
The natural environment where an organism lives and grows.
The role and position of an organism in its ecosystem, including its habitat and behavior.

biology.description: Cell biology, genetics, evolution, and ecology

computer_science.name: Computer Science

cards.front: Define the computer science concept: Algorithm
cards.back: A step-by-step procedure for solving a problem or accomplishing a task.

cards.front: Define the computer science concept: Variable
cards.back: A named storage location in computer memory that can hold data.

cards.front: Define the computer science concept: Function
cards.back: A reusable block of code that performs a specific task.

cards.front: Define the computer science concept: Loop
cards.back: A control structure that repeats a block of code multiple times.

cards.front: Define the computer science concept: Conditional
cards.back: A control structure that executes different code based on whether a condition is true or false.

cards.front: Define the computer science concept: Recursion
cards.back: A programming technique where a function calls itself to solve a problem.

cards.front: Define the computer science concept: Array
cards.back: A collection of elements stored at contiguous memory locations, accessible by index.

cards.front: Define the computer science concept: Linked List
cards.back: A data structure where elements are stored in nodes, each pointing to the next node.

cards.front: Define the computer science concept: Stack
cards.back: A data structure that follows Last-In-First-Out (LIFO) principle.

cards.front: Define the computer science concept: Queue
cards.back: A data structure that follows First-In-First-Out (FIFO) principle.

cards.front: Define the computer science concept: Tree
cards.back: A hierarchical data structure with nodes connected by edges, having one root node.

cards.front: Define the computer science concept: Graph
cards.back: A data structure consisting of vertices (nodes) connected by edges.

cards.front: Define the computer science concept: CPU
cards.back: Central Processing Unit, the brain of the computer that executes instructions.

cards.front: Define the computer science concept: RAM
cards.back: Random Access Memory, temporary storage that the CPU uses for active programs and data.

cards.front: Define the computer science concept: Hard Drive
cards.back: Permanent storage device that stores the operating system, programs, and files.

cards.front: Define the computer science concept: Binary
cards.back: A number system using only 0 and 1, the foundation of all computer operations.

cards.front: Define the computer science concept: Operating System
cards.back: Software that manages computer hardware and provides services for computer programs.

cards.front: Define the computer science concept: Compiler
cards.back: A program that translates source code written in a programming language into machine code.

computer_science.description: Programming, data structures, and computer architecture
